title: Whistleblower Challenges SEC Over Delay on Award Decision
summary: Tipsters have grown frustrated with the length of time it has taken the regulator to determine whether a tip warrants a reward. A purported whistleblower in a foreign corruption case against Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd. says the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission has taken too long to determine whether to grant a reward. He is now asking a federal court to weigh in.

title: Trump Aide Criticizes Medicare for All Plan
summary: Seema Verma says administration pursues superior strategy as Rep. Debbie Dingell defends plan. WASHINGTON-Seema Verma, a top White House health administrator, on Tuesday criticized the Medicare for All health proposal, saying it poses a threat to patient choice and would limit competition.

title: Threats and Blocked Speeches: The Life of Venezuela's Opposition Leader
summary: Resume Subscription. CARACAS, Venezuela-Juan Guaidó betrayed no sign that he was about to move against Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro's brutal regime on the eve of his attempt to ignite a rebellion.

title: Actor Jussie Smollett Not Expected to Return to 'Empire' Next Season
summary: Fox has renewed the drama about a family-run musical empire for a sixth season. Actor Jussie Smollett isn't expected to return to the Fox show "Empire" next season, the network said.

title: Trump-House Legal Fight Could Last Beyond President's Current Term
summary: President is likely to lose in the courts, experts said, although they added he could run out the clock leading up to the 2020 election.. President Trump's legal showdown with Congress may prompt a protracted battle that could last well beyond his current term in office and pose a significant challenge to the authority of House Democrats who are seeking documents related to his business.

title: Ex-Apollo Employees Ordered to Pay Fines in Arbitration Case
summary: The firm was awarded penalties against two former employees over mishandling documents and other violations. Two former Apollo Global Management employees who became competitors of the firm have been ordered to pay damages for mishandling documents and other violations.

title: Warren Buffett's Occidental Play Looks Familiar
summary: Berkshire's preferred-share deal is similar to earlier agreements its CEO reached with Goldman, GE. Berkshire Hathaway Inc.'s investment in Occidental Petroleum Corp. is straight out of Warren Buffett's playbook.

title: Using Encouragement and Threats, Trump Heightens a Gamble on Venezuela
summary: If efforts to oust Maduro fall short, the U.S. will have offered its full-throated backing to a failed uprising with potentially deadly consequences. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration raised its stakes in support of Venezuela's opposition movement, endorsing a call Tuesday by U.S.-backed Juan Guaidó and a small group of military supporters for an uprising, as embattled President Nicolás Maduro worked to crush protests.

title: High Stakes in Caracas
summary: Either democratic forces oust the regime, or Cuba cements its hold.. Venezuela's democratic leaders launched a revolt against Cuban-backed dictator Nicolás Maduro on Tuesday, and the stakes couldn't be higher. Either Venezuelans reclaim their freedom, or instability and misery will continue to radiate from Caracas through the Americas.

title: Apartment Empire Shrinking in Wake of Guilty Pleas
summary: Prosecutors allege that Morgan Management executives and their mortgage brokers obtained about $500 million of loans fraudulently.

title: FDA Clears Philip Morris International Heat-Not-Burn IQOS Device for Sale in U.S.
summary: Philip Morris has spent billions to develop cigarette alternative. The Food and Drug Administration said it would allow two of the world's biggest cigarette makers to start selling in the U.S. a hand-held device that heats but doesn't burn tobacco, though the agency hasn't yet ruled on whether they will be allowed to market it as safer than cigarettes.

title: Tariffs Take You to the Cleaners
summary: Washing-machine taxes launder money from consumers to Whirlpool.. A year after President Trump imposed tariffs up to 50% on imported washing machines, the results are in-and they're grubby. Last week Whirlpool reported a quarterly profit of $471 million, up 400% from a year earlier, even as shipments sank. The CEO credited "margin expansion" due to "pricing actions." In other words, American consumers now pay more to wash their clothes because of government barriers to competition.

title: $2 Trillion From Whom?
summary: Who's going to pay for a bipartisan public works spending blowout?. Who says there's no bipartisanship in Washington? Democrats in Congress visited the White House on Tuesday, and they emerged to say that they and President Trump had agreed to spend $2 trillion on public works. When it comes to spending more money, Washington can always find common ground.

title: Britain's Shale Resignation
summary: The Tories fail to exploit the country's natural-gas riches.. The United Kingdom sits atop enormous reserves of natural gas in shale deposits, extraction of which could create jobs, reduce dependence on the likes of Qatar, and cut carbon emissions. So thank Natascha Engel, the government's now-former "shale tsar," for resigning to blow the whistle on London's failure to exploit this resource.

title: U.S. Seeks to Designate Muslim Brotherhood as Terrorist Group
summary: White House says effort is 'working its way through the internal process'. The Trump administration is seeking to designate the Muslim Brotherhood as a foreign terrorist organization, the White House said, a move that could complicate relations with U.S. allies where Muslim Brotherhood affiliates currently serve in parliament and other government roles.

title: Mondelez Results Boosted by International Sales
summary: Price increases hindered North American comparable sales. Mondelez International Inc. leaned on overseas markets to drive its results in its latest quarter, helping to offset weaker demand in North America.

title: Trumps and Businesses Sue Deutsche Bank and Capital One
summary: Lawsuit is aimed at blocking subpoenas from congressional committees seeking financial records. President Trump, three of his children and his real-estate businesses on Monday filed a federal lawsuit to block Deutsche Bank AG and Capital One Financial Corp. from complying with congressional subpoenas for documents related to him and his family.

title: New York State Tax Return Bill Gets Mixed Democratic Reception
summary: Sen. Brad Hoylman says the bill would help Congress in its oversight role with regard to reviewing President Trump's tax returns. ALBANY, N.Y.-A New York bill that would help members of Congress review President Trump's state tax returns cleared its first legislative hurdle on Tuesday. But even with Democrats controlling the state government, the bill and another measure aimed at combating the effect of presidential pardons face an uncertain path to enactment.

title: Home Depot CFO to Retire After 18-Year Tenure
summary: Carol Tomé served as CFO of one of the world's biggest home-improvement chains since May 2001. Home Depot Inc. said long-serving finance chief Carol Tomé will retire later this year and named an internal successor to the CFO post.

title: Biden, Death and Taxes
summary: Nothing is certain about his grasp of tax policy, but a new study shows the key to employer survival.. One of the oddities of recent public opinion polling is that Americans give President Donald Trump credit for the strong economy even though most of them don't seem to realize he cut their taxes. In a speech in Pittsburgh on Monday, one prominent Democratic voter appeared to be unaware of both the strong economy and the broad tax relief.

title: How to Avoid a 5G Boondoggle
summary: Let businesses experiment and let Washington keep a respectful distance.. Consumers should be heartened that wireless carriers are squabbling about whose network is more "5G." Operators understand that a reputation for network quality remains important to their customers.

title: This Lousy T-Shirt Sparks Joy
summary: My closet remains as cluttered as it ever was. Thanks a lot, Marie Kondo.. I recently watched "Tidying Up with Marie Kondo," a reality TV show about decluttering that has taken the Netflix -watching world by storm. I did this on my wife's recommendation. A busy man, I quickly took in one episode and, feeling I had the gist of things, got started on clothes.

title: 'IBM' Review: Building Big Blue
summary: IBM was originally a holding company cobbled together to please investors. Then Thomas Watson gave the firm a purpose and a sales-driven culture.. Great companies tend to have alluring stories to explain their origins: a charismatic founder, an innovative idea, or a product or technology that goes on to become part of the culture of America itself. IBM's story isn't like that. As explained in a new history of the firm by former IBM executive James Cortada, the company's beginnings trace to the financial ambitions of New York businessman Charles Flint. He had a talent for cobbling together companies to reap rewards through public stock offerings, and in 1911 he stitched several firms into a holding corporation called the Computing-Tabulating-Recording Company, or C-T-R.

title: Impeachment Now Would Be Irresponsible
summary: The ballot box, not Congress, is the venue to adjudicate the case against Trump.. An insightful friend of mine remarked recently that before reading the Mueller report, he was sympathetic with Speaker Nancy Pelosi's reluctance to pursue impeachment of President Trump, but by the time he finished the report he was convinced Congress has a duty to act.

title: Collusion or Russian Disinformation?
summary: How Moscow manipulated U.S. media, lawmakers and intelligence services into propagating a wild theory.. Without intending to, the Mueller report has solved the mystery of the Trump-Russia affair. It shows that Donald Trump and his campaign did not collude with Russia but Russian intelligence used disinformation to create the impression that he did.

title: A Charter-School Principal Won't Go to Prison
summary: 'I'm not the victim,' Ben Chavis says after charges against him are dropped. 'The kids are the victims.'. When Ben Chavis became principal of the American Indian Public Charter School in 2000, it was among the worst middle schools in Oakland, Calif. The building was a mess. There were broken windows and holes in the walls. The gymnasium was carpeted and cluttered with garbage, while food wrappers, cigarette butts and empty beer bottles lined the curb outside.

title: It's Time to Create an American Space Force
summary: Last year China had twice as many launches. Seeing there's a problem doesn't take a rocket scientist.. Telecommunications, precision agriculture, financial markets, transportation, logistics-core components of America's $20 trillion economy depend on technology based in outer space. So does the U.S. military. From secure communications networks to rocket-launch detection systems to the interception of terrorist messages, space capabilities are crucial to national defense. For decades, these capabilities were uncontested. That has changed.

title: Canceling Student-Loan Debt Is a Bad Idea
summary: Three students argue against Sen. Elizabeth Warren's plan..

title: Notable & Quotable: Joe Biden and Anita Hill
summary: 'Biden told me in November 1998, 'It was clear to me from the way she was answering the questions, she was lying.' '. Mollie Hemingwaywriting at the Federalist, April 28:

title: Supply of Analytics Workers Set to Double
summary: Driving the expected boom in analytics experts is a 'flood' of data-savvy college graduates, says Bain & Co.. Chief information officers and other tech recruiters at U.S. firms battling over coveted analytics workers may soon get a reprieve, according to a report by Bain & Co. If they can secure enough foreign-worker visas, that is.

title: Eric Schmidt to Leave Alphabet Board
summary: Schmidt, 64, was appointed CEO of Google in 2001 when it was still privately traded and just three years old. Longtime Google Chief Executive Officer Eric Schmidt will leave the board of the search giant's parent, marking the end of an era for perhaps the company's most well-known figure.

title: Stocks Are Off to Their Best Start in Decades
summary: U.S. stocks close out a strong April, but Alphabet weighs on indexes. Major U.S. stock indexes enjoyed their best four-month start to a year since at least 1999, the latest milestone for a bounceback rally fueled by a more accommodative Federal Reserve and upbeat economic prospects.

title: Apple Results Bring New Kind of Sticker Shock
summary: Stock is near record valuation even as iPhone business struggles. Apple Inc. cleared a low bar with its latest results. Investors are setting up a much higher one going forward.

title: Gilead Sciences CFO Robin Washington to Retire
summary: Ms. Washington also will join the board of Alphabet Inc., according to a statement from the parent company of Google. Gilead Sciences Inc. said its Chief Financial Officer Robin Washington is retiring next year.

title: Dollar Slips as Eurozone's Economy Shows Improvement
summary: Data shows combined gross domestic product grew at faster pace in first quarter. The dollar fell Tuesday after new data showed the eurozone economy grew at a faster pace at the start of 2019, lifting the value of the euro relative to the U.S. currency.

title: GOP Senators Voice Concern Over Stephen Moore at the Fed
summary: Lawmakers cite potential nominee's writings on women, other issues. WASHINGTON-Numerous Senate Republicans expressed concerns Tuesday over the possibility of President Trump nominating conservative commentator Stephen Moore to the Federal Reserve Board of Governors, indicating he would face resistance in the chamber.

title: FDA Orders Tougher Warnings for Sleep Aids
summary: Ambien, Edluar, Zolpimist, Lunesta and Sonata are among insomnia drugs affected by ruling. The Food and Drug Administration said it would require some commonly prescribed sleep aids to carry the agency's toughest boxed warning about serious risks following reports of at least 20 deaths.

title: Boeing Sells $3.5 Billion of Bonds
summary: Offering meets with strong demand from investors. Boeing Co. sold $3.5 billion of bonds Tuesday, providing the company with a liquidity boost as it faces at least $1 billion of costs related to the grounding and reduced production of its 737 MAX airplanes.

title: Gold Climbs as U.S. Dollar Declines
summary: Copper advanced as weak Chinese manufacturing data raised prospects of government stimulus. Price of gold edged higher Tuesday, buoyed by a falling dollar.

title: McDonald's Drives Up Sales With Promotions
summary: Same-store sales beat expectations in U.S. and abroad. McDonald's Corp. said renovated restaurants and new promotions helped boost U.S. sales in the first quarter, though those investments have weighed on profit.

title: Alphabet Shares Post Worst Day Since 2012
summary: Google parent's shares decline as much as 8.6% as investors react to sluggish earnings report. Investors sent shares of Google parent Alphabet Inc. to their worst day in 6 1/2 years, punishing the stock after its quarterly results signaled growth is slowing at the search-engine giant.

title: House Intelligence Chairman Refers Trump Adviser Prince for Criminal Prosecution
summary: Democrat Adam Schiff alleges president's informal adviser lied to Congress about Seychelles meeting with Putin associate. WASHINGTON-The House Intelligence Committee referred Erik Prince, an informal adviser to President Trump, for criminal prosecution on allegations that he misled the panel, marking the latest fallout from special counsel Robert Mueller's probe.

title: Uprising in Caracas Prompts Dueling Demonstrations in Washington
summary: In unusual turn of events, U.S. supporters of Maduro occupy Venezuelan embassy, where pro-rebel protesters are demonstrating. Protesters blocked an ordinarily quiet street outside the Venezuelan Embassy in Washington, chanting and singing in support of the rebels pushing to overthrow strongman Nicolás Maduro.

title: GE Shares Hit Highest Level in Nearly a Month
summary: Once ranked among the most stable of blue-chip companies, GE's stock has been battered in recent years amid the company's complex restructuring. Shares of General Electric Co. recorded their highest close in nearly a month after the struggling conglomerate said it swung to a first-quarter profit.

title: GM Predicts Further Pressure From China
summary: Operating profit fell 11% in quarter; auto maker looks for Beijing to offer incentives to stoke vehicle demand. General Motors Co. warned that weaker results from China will continue to weigh on its bottom line this year as a lingering slowdown in the world's largest vehicle market takes a toll on even the biggest auto-industry players.

title: Peloton Sues Music Publishers, Alleging Anticompetitive Behavior
summary: Stationary-bike maker is responding to publishers' lawsuit alleging copyright infringement. Peloton Interactive Inc. sued a group of music publishers and an industry trade organization, alleging they engaged in anticompetitive behavior by banding together to extract unfair licensing terms for music used on Peloton's video-streaming stationary exercise bikes.

title: Democrats, Trump Agree to Aim for $2 Trillion Infrastructure Package
summary: The two sides didn't discuss how it would be paid for, and Capitol Hill Republicans are unlikely to go along. WASHINGTON-Democratic congressional leaders said President Trump agreed to aim for a $2 trillion infrastructure package in a White House meeting on Tuesday, though the two sides didn't discuss how it would be paid for, and Capitol Hill Republicans are unlikely to go along.

title: Oil Climbs on Report Saudi Arabia Won't Rush to Lift Supply
summary: Analysts look ahead to government data on U.S. inventories. • Oil prices climbed Tuesday, rallying after a report that Saudi Arabia won't rush to lift output following the end of waivers that allowed some countries to buy Iranian crude.

title: Amazon's Freight Push Rattles Logistics Sector
summary: E-commerce giant is expanding logistics operations as it tries to curb shipping costs. Amazon.com Inc. is pushing deeper into logistics as it tries to tamp down transportation costs ahead of a pricey push into one-day shipping, raising potential concerns for freight operators that may end up competing for business with the e-commerce giant that many count as a significant customer.

title: 'Shinto: Discovery of the Divine in Japanese Art' Review: Where Sacred Meets Secular
summary: Works made to venerate holy beings called kami are the backbone of this exhibition in Cleveland.. Cleveland

title: Maryland Takes Step Toward Capping Drug Prices
summary: Governor is poised to sign bill creating panel to review expensive prescription drugs and limit how much agencies will pay for them. Maryland is poised to become the first state to create a panel to review expensive prescription drugs and cap how much public agencies will pay for them.

title: Government Economists Turn to Big Data to Track the Economy
summary: The effort could reshape how a shifting economy is assessed, with implications for policy. A U.S. inflation report released in April offered an early look at a quiet revolution taking place in the way government statisticians are tracking the economy.

title: Health Catalyst Aims to Raise $150 Million to $200 Million in IPO
summary: Share listing would bring company with patient health-record data to public markets. Health-data company Health Catalyst Inc. is planning to raise $150 million to $200 million in its initial public offering, according to people familiar with the matter, bringing one of the first digital-health companies to public markets as technology startups race to list shares.

title: Sri Lankan Islamist Called for Violence on Facebook Before Easter Attacks
summary: Videos filled with hate speech remained online despite locals' complaints. KATTANKUDY, Sri Lanka-A charismatic leader who allegedly helped plan and execute Sri Lanka's Easter bombings called before the attacks for killing non-Muslims in Facebook posts that remained online despite complaints from moderate Muslims who say they asked the company to take them down.

title: Starwood Capital Facing Bondholder Lawsuit in Israel
summary: Two groups of investors say giant real-estate investor didn't sufficiently disclose risks involved in owning mall debt. Starwood Capital Group's struggles in Israel may be deepening after a group of bond investors filed a class-action lawsuit March 24, alleging that the company misrepresented and omitted some risks in a bond prospectus for a group of U.S. shopping centers.

title: U.S. Government Bonds Gain Amid Mixed Global Data
summary: Factory activity weakens in China and Europe's economy is improving, data show. U.S. government bond prices rose Tuesday as a raft of mixed data provided investors with an uncertain picture of global growth.

title: Facebook's Private Gamble Goes Public
summary: Facebook's privacy-focused redesign is a risky bet on a very public stage. Facebook is growing antisocial or, at the very least, a bit cliquey. But the social network's shift from public to private communications may come at the expense of developers and advertisers, and it is unclear whether the undertaking will garner more users or less.

title: Trump Repeats Calls for Fed to Stimulate Growth
summary: President wants policy makers to cut interest rates and resume bond-buying program. President Trump called for the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates by 1 percentage point and resume its crisis-era bond-buying program to stimulate economic growth.

title: Pete Buttigieg Releases Tax Returns
summary: The South Bend mayor is the latest Democratic 2020 contender to make his tax information public as President Trump continues to resist doing so. WASHINGTON-Democratic presidential candidate Pete Buttigieg released 10 years of tax returns Tuesday, showing he earned a $30,000 advance in 2017 to write a book that was released ahead of his White House bid.

title: Facebook Gets New Look as Zuckerberg Declares New Era
summary: Social platform launches redesign meant to encourage less-public discourse while curbing abuse, misinformation. Facebook Inc. rolled out a substantial redesign of its website and mobile app, as Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg seeks to address criticism of the social-media giant's influence by nudging users toward different types of engagement and more private communication tools.

title: 'Strange Fruit': Still Haunting at 80
summary: The anti-lynching song, recorded in 1939 in an iconic version by Billie Holiday, remains potent and piercing today..

title: NSA Reports 75% Increase in Unmasking U.S. Identities Under Foreign Surveillance Law in 2018
summary: The National Security Agency, responsible for electronic eavesdropping, disclosed the identities of people or entities that are normally redacted in intelligence reports. The National Security Agency revealed to federal agencies the identities of almost 17,000 U.S. residents or corporations whose information was collected under a foreign surveillance law in 2018, registering about a 75% increase in unmaskings over the previous year, according to an annual transparency report released Tuesday.

title: Pfizer's Pipeline Makes Progress as Sales Grow
summary: Quarterly profit rises to $3.88 billion. Pfizer Inc.'s new portfolio of prescription drugs lifted sales during the first quarter as the company said it continues to make progress on growing through its internal pipeline.

title: 'The Phoenix' Review: An Exciting Life Turned to Ash
summary: An opera about Mozart's collaborator Lorenzo Da Ponte dulls down that librettist's picaresque story.. Houston

title: Bullpens Struggle to Provide Relief
summary: The bullpenning revolution defined the 2018 baseball season, but starters are on pace to outperform relievers this year. "Bullpenning," the practice of eschewing a traditional starting pitcher in favor of a parade of relievers, defined the 2018 baseball season. What began as a radical approach to navigate the playoffs quickly emerged as a full-blown movement, and it seemed like a paradigm shift bound to fundamentally change the sport forever.

title: Altice USA Buys Streaming-Video Network Cheddar for $200 Million
summary: Cheddar founder and CEO Jon Steinberg is set to become president of Altice News, overseeing Cheddar, News 12 and i24News. Cable operator Altice USA Inc. agreed to acquire streaming-video network Cheddar Inc. for $200 million, an all-cash deal that is expected to raise the profile of the company's news division.

title: KKR Profit Climbs, Assets Rise
summary: Private-equity firm's distributable earnings land slightly above expectations. KKR & Co. reported a sharply higher first-quarter profit, as it benefited from sales of stakes in companies like GoDaddy Inc.

title: Warren Buffett Helps Occidental Raise Anadarko Ante, but at Steep Price
summary: Berkshire Hathaway's $10 billion cash infusion should help Occidental ink the deal for Anadarko, but it is expensive. Warren Buffett knows a good deal when he sees one. The Sage of Omaha's Berkshire Hathaway is shelling out $10 billion to Occidental Petroleum to help its takeover efforts for Anadarko Petroleum .

title: U.S. Kills Militant Linked to Deadly Attack on American Troops in Somalia
summary: Al-Shabaab commander was killed April 19 as he rode a motorcycle near a village in southern Somalia. An April 19 U.S. airstrike in Somalia killed the al-Shabaab militant believed responsible for an American soldier's death last year in an attack on an isolated outpost, according to the U.S. military.

title: Please Ask Ilhan Omar About Terror in Somalia
summary: As a longtime scholar of Somalia, I wonder why Rep. Omar avoids sharing her perspective on the militant Islamic terrorist group Harakat al-Shabaab.. Karl Rove criticizes Rep. Ilhan Omar for her dismissive comments about the devastation caused by the 9/11 attacks ("Ilhan Omar Blames America First," op-ed, April 25). As a scholar of Somalia, I find her silence on contemporary Somali affairs equally disturbing. Why won't Rep. Omar share her perspective on the militant Somali Islamic terrorist group al-Shabaab? Is she supportive or critical of its suicide bombings in and around Mogadishu and in Kenya? Is she troubled by its ties to other jihadist murderers?

title: Measles Isn't America's Only Vaccine Problem
summary: There is an urgent need to improve the uptake of the measles vaccine, but it would seem that increasing influenza vaccination rates would have an even greater public health payout.. As a pediatrician and former Epidemic Intelligence Service officer with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, I am fully supportive of your editorial "'They Have to Get the Shots'" (April 27). It is frustrating to see the resurgence of a completely preventable disease with almost all cases occurring in unvaccinated individuals.

title: Health Mandates Need to Have Some Caveats
summary: The main problem is the health insurance mandate doesn't come with caveats. Automobile insurance is also required (mandated), but some level of driving competence is also required.. Regarding Alan Binder's "The Individual Mandate Is Here to Stay" (op-ed, April 15): The main problem is the mandate doesn't come with caveats. Automobile insurance is also required (mandated), but some level of driving competence is also required. And those who operate their vehicles recklessly and with little regard for their fellow drivers can have their licenses taken away. That doesn't happen with health insurance. I live in North Carolina, which carries the distinction of being one of the top 15 fattest states in the country. There are any number of people here who are morbidly obese. I can also talk the talk from that standpoint, as I was diagnosed last year with Type 2 diabetes. I promptly changed my diet, got off the couch, exercised more and lost 30 pounds, all without the need of any prescription drugs.

title: Bretton Woods Failed When Fiscal and Monetary Discipline Did
summary: The fixed exchange-rate regime after World War II worked well until Congress and the Federal Reserve broke through their guardrails.. Judy Shelton argues that a return to a Bretton Woods-type monetary regime would guarantee monetary and financial stability ("The Case for Monetary Regime Change," op-ed, April 22). This system of fixed exchange rates, anchored by backing the dollar with gold, did work reasonably well from its inception in 1948 until about 1965. However, it was destroyed by our failure to maintain fiscal and monetary discipline.

title: A Frugal Athlete Will Win the Prize for Living Wisely
summary: In this time of student-debt crisis, public-debt crisis, credit-card abuse and the culture of simply spending what you don't have, everyone should look to Christian Wilkins as a role model.. In this time of student-debt crisis, public-debt crisis, credit-card abuse and the culture of simply spending what you don't have, everyone should look to Christian Wilkins as a role model ("The Most Frugal Player in the Draft," Sports, April 24). This young man has exhibited fiscal discipline, earned his undergraduate and master's degrees in less than four years and worked at a job through college-all before he even steps on an NFL field.

title: Can a Doorbell Camera Actually Make You Safer?
summary: The smart security devices help ensure our packages are in the right hands, but they may open the door to a more nefarious element: hackers. UNTIL RECENTLY, home security systems tended to be pricey, call-in-an-expert affairs. And if your permanent, custom system went on the fritz and you couldn't recall the passcode to silence the alarm, it seemed far simpler to go into moaning meltdown mode than to deal with it.

title: Arconic to Name Two CEOs as It Charts Path to Breakup
summary: Metal and parts maker to sell some business lines, but will keep building-products unit. Arconic Inc. said it plans to appoint two chief executives ahead of its planned breakup into two public companies by the middle of next year.

title: U.S. Says Employee at Cannabis Staffing Agency Can't Use Bankruptcy
summary: Justice Department says federal marijuana ban prevents Oregon woman from remaining in chapter 13. The Justice Department says an Oregon woman can't use bankruptcy because she works for a staffing agency that recruits employees for the cannabis industry, part of a broader department policy imposing the federal pot ban on individuals whose income is tied to commercial marijuana.

title: Bellevue Tests Its Preparedness for Ebola, Other Infectious Diseases
summary: Fire, police, city and medical workers ran two-day drill, acting out dozens of steps, while nurses and doctors evaluated them. New York City saw its first and only patient with the deadly Ebola virus 4½ years ago. Since then, emergency and health-care workers have been training for the next patient.

title: GM Loses Ground to Ford
summary: First-quarter results offered signs GM is giving up some of the lead it has built. General Motors has raced ahead of Ford Motor on the stock market over the past three years. First-quarter results offered tentative signs that Ford could make up lost ground.

title: GE Slows Cash Burn as It Shrinks
summary: Conglomerate warns cash flow will be negative in second quarter but sticks to 2019 forecasts. General Electric Co. swung to a first-quarter profit and reported stronger cash production than expected, but cautioned that the grounding of Boeing Co. 's 737 Max airliner could hurt the timing of its cash flows.

title: Canadian Economy Contracted Slightly in February
summary: GDP falls 0.1%, falling short of expectations. OTTAWA-The Canadian economy contracted slightly in February, falling short of forecasts and fueling expectations that the Bank of Canada will keep interest rates on hold through the rest of this year.

title: Oculus Quest Review: A $400 Taste of the Future of Gaming
summary: We're still years away from virtual reality's iPhone moment, but the $400 Oculus Quest proves VR already does gaming really well. Years from now, virtual reality might be a crucial part of your everyday life. A headset or a pair of special glasses will transport you to a meeting room halfway across the world or onto the sidelines at the Super Bowl.

title: Mexican Economy Contracted in First Quarter
summary: Declines in industrial production, services weigh on economic growth, posing a challenge for new government. MEXICO CITY-Mexico's economy contracted in the first quarter of the year, posing a challenge for the new government of President Andrés Manuel López Obrador, who has pledged to accelerate growth after years of modest expansion.

title: Blue Apron Still Isn't Appetizing
summary: The meal-kit company has slashed costs but it has also lost customers and revenue. Blue Apron, the troubled meal-kit business, promised investors that it would be profitable on an adjusted basis by the first quarter of this year. To its credit, the company has held true to that forecast. But until it stops hemorrhaging customers and starts growing revenue, investors have no reason to order up its shares.

title: Democrats Pepper Voters With Competing Health-Care Ideas
summary: Candidates' proposals range from expanding Affordable Care Act to ending employer-based insurance. On expanding health coverage, Democrats' 2020 hopefuls have agreed to disagree.

title: Cosco Shipping Units to Sell U.S. Long Beach Container Terminal for $1.78 Billion
summary: Cosco Shipping expects to book a pretax disposal gain of $1.09 billion from the sale. Orient Overseas (International) Ltd. said Tuesday that it would sell the Long Beach Container Terminal business in Southern California to a consortium led by Macquarie Infrastructure Partners for $1.78 billion.

title: New Airport Terminals Where Killing Time Has Its Perks
summary: From New Orleans to Istanbul, new airports and terminals offer enough distractions (beignets, anyone?) to make even long delays tolerable. SHORT OF THE HOSPITAL or the DMV, people dread few destinations more than the airport. Interminable schleps, stale $18 sandwiches and seating that makes the cabin on Air Torquemada feel relatively comfy seem to be the norm. While the indignities of air travel are as immutable as the physics that keep you airborne, the designers of these new-breed airports have found ways to inject beauty, efficiency and even fun into your travels.

title: India Arrests Man Who Allegedly Planned Suicide Attack in Kerala
summary: Law-enforcement agencies are stepping up terror probes after the Sri Lanka attacks. NEW DELHI-An alleged follower of Zahran Hashim-the suspected organizer of the deadly Easter bombings in Sri Lanka-was in custody in India after investigators said he conspired to launch a suicide attack in the southern state of Kerala.

title: Google's Biggest Business Doesn't Click
summary: Surprising slowdown in advertising revenue undercuts internet giant's key strength. Google's ad machine seems to have slipped a gear.

title: Democrat Abrams Says She Won't Run for U.S. Senate in Georgia
summary: Democrats had urged her for months to try to unseat GOP Sen. David Perdue. ATLANTA-Democrat Stacey Abrams said she wouldn't be running for U.S. Senate in Georgia next year, after months of urging by Democratic leaders who considered her their best shot at unseating incumbent Republican Sen. David Perdue.

title: Does a Shazam for Clothing Exist?
summary: Our men's fashion editor tested various methods-both digital and analog-that people can use to identify a coveted garment spotted on a celebrity or out in the wild. I WAS SITTING in a bar recently when a song came on that I almost, just almost, recognized. Ten years ago, my inability to suss out this track would have gnawed at me for hours, but thanks to the now-classic iPhone app Shazam, I could instantly deduce it was "Making Plans for Nigel" by British rockers XTC. I wondered, not for the first time, why Shazam's functionality hasn't infiltrated the rest of our lives, specifically our quest for clothes. Often, I'll see an item online-say, the three-pocket, lightly distressed chore jacket that David Beckham wore on "The Late Late Show with James Corden" (pictured above)-and wish I could chase down the same one. While pocket-packed chore coats are hardly rare, the distressing and apparently sturdy rivets on Mr. Beckham's convinced me it was special. With the bottomless sea of apps out there, surely one could let me upload a photo of his coat and quickly identify its make and model. When I set out to find this fantasy version of Shazam, I ultimately learned it doesn't exist, but I may have stumbled on a more old-school solution along the way.
